title: From John O'Groats to Land's End; Or, 1372 miles on foot; A book of days and chronicle of adventures by two pedestrians on tour
author: Naylor, John Anderton
snippet: By fancy wrapt, where tombs are crusted grey,  I seem by moon-illumined graves to stray,  Where now a mouldering pile is faintly seen--  The old deserted church of Hassendean,  Where slept my fathers in their natal clay  Till Teviot waters rolled their bones away.

title: From John O'Groats to Land's End; Or, 1372 miles on foot; A book of days and chronicle of adventures by two pedestrians on tour
author: Naylor, John Anderton
snippet: The oldkirk of Hassendean had been dismantled in 1693, but its burial-groundcontinued to be used until 1795, when an ice-flood swept away allvestiges both of the old kirk and the churchyard.

title: From John O'Groats to Land's End; Or, 1372 miles on foot; A book of days and chronicle of adventures by two pedestrians on tour
author: Naylor, John Anderton
snippet: In about four miles we reached Hassendean and the RiverTeviot, for we were now in Teviot Dale, along which we were to walk,following the river nearly to its source in the hills above.

title: From John O'Groats to Land's End; Or, 1372 miles on foot; A book of days and chronicle of adventures by two pedestrians on tour
author: Naylor, John Anderton

title: Reminiscences of Yarrow. Edited and annotated by ... Professor Veitch, LL.D. Illustrated by Tom Scott ... Second edition
author: Russell, James
snippet: Butthe great, because an annual, occasion was the arrival of the minister's victual from Hassendean.

title: Reminiscences of Yarrow. Edited and annotated by ... Professor Veitch, LL.D. Illustrated by Tom Scott ... Second edition
author: Russell, James
snippet: There are three wives in Hassendean,And ane in Braidie-Yairds,
